1 3-pound chicken
1 large carrot, cut into large pieces
1 large leek, white and pale-green parts only, halved
½ medium onion
Kosher salt

⅔ cup long-grain white rice (preferably Carolina)
Freshly ground black pepper and olive oil (for serving)
RECIPE PREPARATION
Real Talk: This soup is incredible due to its velvety, luxurious texture. Everyone you serve it to will be impressed. BUT you need to fully reduce the broth to 2 quarts, which should only take a half an hour; you can’t even get through an entire episode of Game of Thrones in that time. So have patience, grasshopper! And you’ll also get to brag to said guests that you learned how to temper eggs (cooking them without scrambling) thanks to this recipe.

Bring chicken, carrot, leek, onion, and 4 quarts water to a simmer in a large pot; cook until chicken is cooked through, 45–60 minutes. Transfer chicken to a plate; discard carrot, leek, and onion. Let chicken sit until cool enough to handle.

Continue to cook broth over medium-high heat until reduced to about 2 quarts, about 30 minutes. Season with salt.

Meanwhile, shred meat from thighs and legs; set aside (reserve breasts for another use).

Whisk eggs and lemon juice in a medium bowl until foamy and no streaks remain. Whisking constantly, add 1 cup hot chicken broth, a couple teaspoons at a time at first (don’t pour too much hot broth too quickly or you’ll end up with scrambled eggs), then increasing to a steady stream, until fully incorporated.

Meanwhile, reduce heat to medium and add rice to broth, stirring vigorously so rice doesn’t stick to bottom of pot; cook 5 minutes. Add reserved chicken and continue to cook until chicken is heated through and rice is tender, about 5 minutes more.

Whisking vigorously, slowly drizzle in tempered egg mixture, a couple teaspoons at a time at first, then increasing to a steady stream, until fully incorporated (it will cook instantly).

Reduce heat to medium-low and cook until soup is slightly thickened and velvety and luxurious-looking, about 5 minutes. Remove from heat and season with salt. Let sit 10 minutes to thicken up slightly.

Divide soup among bowls; season with pepper and drizzle with oil.

Do Ahead: Soup can be made 3 days ahead; cover and chill.
Add a bit of saffron and/or rose syrup to the sugar syrup

"Pesto is the sauce the Genoese invented as a vehicle for the fragrance of a basil like no other, their own. Olive oil, garlic, pine nuts, butter, and grated cheese are the only other components. Pesto is never cooked, or heated, and while it may on occasion do good things for vegetable soup, it has just one great role: to be the most seductive of all sauces for pasta... Genoese cooks insist that if it isn’t made in a mortar with a pestle, it isn’t pesto. Ingredients: 1 cup parmigiano reggiano,2.5 lb tagliatelle,24 oz San Marzano whole peeled plum tomatoes,2 cups white wine,0.25 tsp nutmeg,2 cups milk,  pepper to taste,  salt to taste,1.5 lb ground beef,6 tbsp butter (unsalted),2 tbsp olive oil,1 cup onion(s),1.33 cup celery,1.33 cup carrot
Cooking Instructions:
Prep:
Mince the 1 1/3 cup carrot, 1 1/3 cup celery and 1 cup onion into tiny cubes.

Mash up the 28 oz can of plum tomatoes in their juice with your hands and weigh out 24 oz of it for this recipe.

Directions:
Put 2 tbsp oil, 6 tbsp butter, and the chopped onion into a large pot all at once (i.e. do not melt the butter first). Turn the heat on to medium. Cook and stir the onion until it has become translucent, then add the chopped celery and carrot. Cook for about 2 min, stirring vegetables to coat them well with the butter and oil.

Add 1.5 ground beef (Note: can alternatively use 1 lb beef with 1/2 lb pork), 2 large pinches of salt, and several grindings of black pepper. Using a fork, break the meat up into small crumbles, stir well, and cook until the beef has lost its raw, red color.

Add 2 cups milk and let it simmer gently, stirring frequently, until it has reduced almost all the way. (Note: It should look like there's no liquid in the pot, more like just juicy meat mixture.) This should take ~20-30 minutes.

Add 1/4 tsp nutmeg and 2 cups white wine. Let it simmer, stirring frequently, until it has reduced almost all the way, just like the milk. This should take about another 20-30 minutes.

Add the tomatoes and stir thoroughly to coat all ingredients well. When the tomatoes begin to bubble, turn the heat down very low so that the sauce cooks at the laziest of simmers. Put a diffuser underneath the pot to help reduce the heat even further. 

Cook, uncovered, for 4.5 hours, stirring every 10-15 minutes. While the sauce is cooking, you are likely to find that it begins to dry out and the fat separates from the meat. Spoon the fat off the top if desired, and to keep the sauce from sticking to the pot, add 1/2 cup of water whenever necessary. At the end, the sauce should be thick - not at all watery, but not dried up.

Toss with 2.5 to 3 lb cooked tagliatelle and serve with freshly grated Parmesan on the side.

2 – 2 1/2 pounds chuck roast
1 medium onion, chopped finely
6-8 cloves of garlic, pressed

2 tablespoons tomato paste
2 tablespoons balsamic vinegar
1 (28 ounce can) crushed tomatoes
1 (14 ounce can) diced tomatoes
2 bay leaves
a few sprigs of fresh thyme

1 teaspoon sugar

salt to taste

Season both sides of the chuck roast with salt and pepper. Heat the oil in a large, dutch oven over medium high heat. Add the beef into the pot and allow it to sear on each side for 5 minutes. Add the onions to the skillet and let them sweat for 4-5 minutes or until they turn translucent. Add the garlic and let cook for another 1-2 minutes.
STOVE TOP: Deglaze the pan with 1 cup of beef broth. Add the remaining 2 tablespoons of beef broth to a bowl along with the tomato paste and balsamic vinegar and use a whisk to combine. Add the mixture to the dutch oven and stir to mix. Add the crushed tomatoes, diced tomatoes, bay leaves, fresh thyme, basil, sugar, and red pepper flakes. Allow the sauce to gain a simmer, stir once. Cover and lower the heat to the lowest setting and let cook for 2 1/2 – 3 1/2 hours or until the meat easily shreds with two forks. Mine took about 3 hours to get the meat to just fall apart. Season with salt to taste. Feel free to skim any excess fat off the top and remove the bay leaves and basil leaves before serving. Serve over pappardelle with a sprinkle of parsley and freshly grated parmesan.
SLOW COOKER: Transfer the meat, onion, and garlic mixture to a slow cooker. Add the 1 cup of beef broth to the slow cooker. Whisk the remaining 2 tablespoons of beef broth in a bowl with the tomato paste and balsamic vinegar. Add the mixture to the slow cooker along with the crushed tomatoes, diced tomatoes, bay leaves, fresh thyme, basil, sugar, and red pepper flakes. Cover and let cook on the slow setting for 6-8 hours. Use 2 forks to shred the meat. You’ll know it’s done when it falls apart easily. Season with salt to taste. Cooking Instructions:
Halve both onions through root end. Using the tip of your knife, cut a V-shaped notch around root to remove it (this will ensure that all slices separate when you cut the onion).

Place 1 onion half on your cutting board so root end is facing you, then thinly slice onion lengthwise, starting at one side and working all the way to the other (so your knife runs through the root halfway through, not starting or ending at the root end). You’re going for slices that are ¼"–⅛" thick.

Repeat same slicing procedure for remaining onion halves. It’s a lot of onion! But it will cook down quite a bit, so it’s best to start with a large quantity.

Heat 2 Tbsp. butter in a large saucepan over medium until melted and sizzling. You can use a skillet to cook the onions, but a pan with high sides will keep the onions from flipping out onto your stove. Using a pan that also has a wide base gives water room to evaporate, allowing the onions to caramelize rather than steam.

Instead of dumping in all of the onions at once, which would fill the pot and make it hard to stir (which would then cause the ones on the bottom to cook faster), start by adding just a couple of large handfuls to the pot. Cook, stirring, until onions are soft and starting to turn translucent, 1–2 minutes. Stir in a few more handfuls of onion and repeat cooking and stirring process until you’ve added all the onions. Season with a pinch of salt.

Reduce heat to medium-low and continue to cook onions, stirring every few minutes to prevent them from sticking and coloring too much in any one place, until blonde-colored, 15–20 minutes. This is the point of doneness for French onion soup! If you feel like onions are getting too brown around the edges or they’re sticking, reduce your heat a bit.

If you’re going for onions that are both softer and more caramelized (say for a patty melt or onion dip), keep cooking, stirring regularly, until onions are unmistakably golden brown, another 15–20 minutes. Because most of the water has cooked off at this point, there might be some bare spots where the pot could start to burn. If this happens, stir in a splash of broth or water. The liquid will dissolve the cooked-on bits, which the onions will re-absorb.

For extra-dark onions, the kind that make a great burger topping, cook until they start to almost blacken around the edges and go slightly crisp, another 10–15 minutes. This requires constant attention so they don’t burn!

Let onions cool in the saucepan, then use or transfer to an airtight container and chill. They will keep up to 1 week.

Cooking Instructions:

Prep:
Cover the outside bottom and sides of a 9 x 2 1/2-inch spring-form pan with a double thickness of aluminum foil.  Grease the pan with butter or cooking spray. Line the bottom with a round of waxed paper; grease the waxed paper. Take out a second pan large enough to fit the first one in.

Fill a teapot with water and turn on the heat.  Preheat the oven to 350 degrees.

Cooking Instructions:
B.B.R.R.R.
1. Brine
2. Brush
3. Rub
4. Roast
5. Rest

BRINE
Before you begin brining you need to figure out how much liquid you will need to fully submerge the protein. This will allow you to calculate the amount of salt and sugar needed. To do this, simply place the protein into the container and, using a measuring cup, calculate the amount of liquid it takes to completely submerge your protein. 

Now that you have that info, you can figure the proper salt and sugar ratios. If using kosher salt, add ¼ cup per quart of liquid. If using table salt, add 2 tablespoons per quart.  **Take the protein out of the water before adding the salt.**

If you are using pieces of protein, the average weight of the pieces (not the total weight) is used to calculate the brining time. Example: 3 one-pound pieces of protein = 1 hour of brining (not 3 hours). **The exception to this rule is pieces weighing 8 ounces or less; those should brine for no more than 30 minutes.**

1) Mix together liquid, salt, and sugar (if using) until salt and sugar are fully dissolved.
2) Add the protein to the brine, making sure that it is fully submerged.
3) Leave the protein in the brine for an hour per pound. Store in the refrigerator, as the brine must be kept cold at all times during the process.

BRUSH
If you're breading the chicken or putting on a specific marinade, ignore the next two steps. If not, brush the chicken with olive oil or butter now.

RUB
Rub desired spices onto the chicken.

ROAST
Roast the chicken breasts for 12-18 minutes at 450°F, depending on their thickness. Stick a meat thermometer into the thickest part of each chicken breast. When the internal temperature of each reaches 165°F, it's fully cooked.

REST
Let the chicken rest for 10 minutes before cutting into it.

Cooking Instructions:
Coquito Puertorriqueño:

PART 1 - Spice Reduction
Measure out a 1-inch piece of fresh ginger and peel it. Place it into a small pot with 12 oz water. Add 6 sticks of cinnamon, 6 whole cloves, and 4 anise stars to the pot. 

Boil these ingredients for 10 min with the lid on at a medium high temperature and then drop to a medium temperature for 10 more minutes.

When the water turns a caramel color, pull the pot off the heat and set it aside to cool. In Part 2, you'll mix this reduction with the rest of the ingredients.

PART 2 - Coquito
Take out vanilla ice cream to soften a little.

Thoroughly mix 16 oz coconut milk, 15 oz coconut cream, 12 oz evaporated milk, and 14 oz condensed milk in a blender. Blend in 1 tsp vanilla, 1 tsp ground cinnamon, a pinch of salt.

Then blend in 2 cups of softened vanilla ice cream and the spice reduction from Part 1. Finally, mix in white rum, such as Bacardi or Don Q, to taste.

If there are large chunks of coconut cream, you can strain them out before pouring the coquito into a glass bottle for storage. For best results, let the coquito sit in the fridge overnight so the flavors will be better.
Notes: To make halal version, simply leave out the rum.

When the finished potatoes have cooled enough to touch, remove their skin and dice them. Let the diced potatoes dry out to ensure maximum crispiness.

Meanwhile, chop the corned beef finely and dice the onion.

Pre-cook the corned beef until it's crispy and set it aside. Fry the onions and potatoes over medium heat until they start to brown. 

Meanwhile, in a small mixing bowl, combine 1 tbsp slightly crushed mustard seeds, 1 tbsp parsley, and 1 tsp sage.

When the potatoes and onions are ready, add back the corned beef along with seasoning mixture and 2-3 tbsp butter. Then add salt, fresh cracked black pepper, and a sprinkle of garlic powder to taste. Fry this mixture until crispy. 

If serving the hash with eggs, add them in one of these two ways:

Ingredients: 0.5 cup parmigiano reggiano,1 tsp nutmeg,  pepper to taste,1 tsp parsley,0.5 cup milk,1 tbsp flour,1 tbsp butter (unsalted),1 cup spinach,2 cloves garlic,8 oz mushrooms,1 tbsp olive oil,1  spaghetti squash
Cooking Instructions:
Prep:

Mince the garlic, chop the mushrooms, and measure out the spinach. Scoop the squash meat out into a large mixing bowl, keeping the body to use as bowls.

Main:
Sauté the mushrooms in olive oil, adding the garlic once they are about half done. Add the spinach and place a cover on the pan to help the spinach steam. Mix the veggies into the squash.

To make a roux, melt 1 tbsp butter and whisk in 1 tbsp flour, removing any lumps. Slowly whisk in the milk, once again breaking up lumps. Season with 1 tsp nutmeg, 1 tsp parsley, and pepper to taste. Whisk in the parmesan, removing lumps as it melts. Mix the sauce thoroughly with the veggies.

THE BATTER 
1 cup milk 
¾ cup all-purpose flour 
2 eggs 
⅛ teaspoon salt 
FOR COOKING THE CRESPELLE
1 to 1½ tablespoons butter 
An 8-inch nonstick skillet ***

Using a mixer and its whisk attachment, pour in 1 cup milk with 3/4 cup sifted flour. 
1. Put the milk in a bowl and add the flour gradually, sifting it through a sieve if possible, while you mix steadily with a fork or whisk to avoid making lumps. When you have added all the flour, beat the mixture until it is evenly blended. 

2. Add the eggs, one at a time, beating them in rapidly with a fork. When both eggs have been incorporated into the batter, add the salt, stirring to distribute it. 

3. Lightly smear the bottom of the skillet with some of the butter. Turn on the heat under the pan to medium low.

4. Give the batter a good stirring, and pour 2 tablespoons of it into the pan. Tilt and rotate the pan to distribute the batter evenly. 

5. As soon as the batter sets and becomes firm and speckled brown, slip a spatula underneath it and flip it over to cook the other side. Stack the finished crespelle on a plate. 

6. Coat the bottom of the skillet with a tiny amount of butter, and repeat the procedure described above until you’ve used up all the batter. Remember to stir the batter each time before pouring it into the pan. 

**Ahead-of-time note: If you are doing them days ahead of time, interweave them with wax paper before refrigerating. They will stay fresh for up to 3 days.
Notes:
Source: "Essentials of Classic Italian Cooking" by Marcella Hazan, loc 5236 of the Kindle edition

Ingredients: salt to taste,0.5 cup basil (fresh),2 tbsp parmigiano reggiano,4 oz ricotta salata,1 tbsp butter (unsalted),1 cup arborio rice,4.25 cups vegetable stock,1 lb tomato(es),1  onion(s),3 cloves garlic,1  eggplant(s),4 tbsp olive oil

INGREDIENTS
FOR THE FILLING:
6 tablespoons (85 grams) unsalted butter, at room temperature
¾ cup (85 grams) confectioners’ sugar
¾ cup (85 grams) almond flour
¼ teaspoon salt
2 large eggs, at room temperature
1 tablespoon rum (optional)
1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract
TO ASSEMBLE:
2 9 1/2-inch-diameter circles puff-pastry dough (from a 14- to 17-ounce package; 396-482 grams), cold
1 whole almond or dried bean, for the charm

PREPARATION
TO MAKE THE FILLING:
Working with a mixer or by hand, beat the butter and sugar together until creamy and light. Beat in the almond flour and the salt. Mix in 1 whole egg, then the white from the second egg (reserve the yolk). Mix in the rum, if using, and the extract. Cover, and refrigerate for at least 1 hour.
Mix the yolk with 1 teaspoon cold water; cover, and refrigerate until needed.
TO ASSEMBLE:
Place one circle of dough on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper. Spread the filling evenly over the dough, leaving a 1-inch border bare. Press the charm into the filling. Moisten the border with cold water, position the second circle of dough over the filling and press around the border with your fingertips to seal well. Using the back of a table knife, scallop the edges by pushing into the dough (about 1/4- to 1/2-inch deep) every 1/2 inch or so. Refrigerate for at least 30 minutes.
Heat the oven to 425. Brush a thin layer of the reserved yolk glaze over the top of the galette, avoiding the border (if glaze drips down the rim, the galette won’t rise). With the point of a paring knife, etch a design into the top of the galette, taking care not to pierce the dough. Cut 6 small slits in the top as steam vents.
Turn the heat down to 400, and bake for 30 to 40 minutes, until the galette is puffed and deeply golden. Check after 20 minutes, and tent loosely with foil if it’s browning too much or too fast. Transfer to a rack, and cool for at least 15 minutes (the galette may deflate — that’s puff pastry for you). Serve warm or at room temperature.

Cheesecake
10 ounces 72% dark chocolate, chopped

3 large eggs

1/4 cup Dutch cocoa powder

Chocolate Hazelnut Ganache:
4 ounces (1/2 cup) Nutella
4 ounces (1/2 cup) heavy cream

* Requires overnight preparation

Prep:
Cover the outside bottom and sides of a 9 x 2 1/2-inch spring-form pan with a double thickness of aluminum foil.  Grease the pan with butter or cooking spray. Line the bottom with a round of waxed paper; grease the waxed paper. Take out a second pan large enough to fit the first one in.

Preheat the oven to 350F for pre-baking the crust. Take out the 24 oz. cream cheese to soften.

Directions:
CRUST
Place ~30 Nabisco chocolate wafers and 1 cup blanched hazelnuts in the food processor and pulse until finely ground. Mix in 3 tbsp sugar. Then, add 6 tbsp MELTED butter and pulse until the mixture forms coarse crumbs, resembling wet sand.

Scrape into prepared pan and use fingers to press into the bottom and up the side of the pan, making sure the crust is even. Bake in oven for 8 minutes. Place on wire rack to cool. Keep oven temperature.

CHEESECAKE FILLING
Prepare cheesecake filling by placing 10 oz. of chopped chocolate in a double boiler until smooth and creamy. Remove from heat and let cool for a few minutes.

Set a pot of water to boil on the stove while the filling is made. 

In an electric or stand mixer, beat 24 oz. cream cheese and 3/4 cup plain 2% greek yogurt until smooth and fluffy. Add in 1 1/4 cups sugar and 1/4 cup Dutch cocoa powder and beat again until smooth. Then add in 3 eggs and 1 egg yolk, blending until there is a silky consistency. Fold in melted chocolate until thoroughly combined.

Pour chocolate cheesecake filling over the cooled crust and smooth the top with a spatula. Tap a few times to release any air in the batter. Place the spring-form pan in the larger pan, and put them in the oven. Carefully fill the larger pan with boiling water from the teapot, until it reaches about halfway up the sides of the spring-form pan. 

Bake for 55-60 minutes, or until the center no longer jiggles. Cool the cheesecake 10 minutes, then run a knife around the crust to loosen it. Chill the cheesecake a minimum of 4 hours in fridge, although overnight is best.

GANACHE
In a medium saucepan, heat 1/2 cup heavy cream over low heat to avoid curdling. Add 1/2 cup of Nutella and stir until smooth. Add in 2 ounces of chopped dark chocolate and stir until melted. Pour or drizzle over the center of the chocolate cheesecake and spread to outer edges to help cover any cracks. If desired, top with toasted hazelnuts.

Serve while ganache is warm or place in refrigerator to cool. Cut into 12-16 slices and enjoy!

1 cup long-grain rice

1 small cinnamon stick
1 tsp mustard seeds
1 teaspoon turmeric
1/4 teaspoon salt

3 1/2 cups chicken stock, SEPARATED
2 tablespoons vegetable oil
4 large skinless boneless chicken breast halves, cubed

1 tablespoon ginger
2 tablespoons curry powder
salt and pepper, to taste
1/4 cup plain yogurt, plus more for serving***

1/8 cup cornstarch, if needed
1/2 cup water, if needed


Prep:
Soak 1 cup basmati rice.

Mince 2 small onions and peel large cloves of garlic and set aside. 

Measure and separate the chicken broth into 2.5 cups and 1 cup.

Directions:
Melt 2 tbsp ghee in a medium saucepan. Add half the chopped onion and cook until soft.  Add 1 tsp turmeric, 1/4 salt, and 1 small cinnamon stick. Cook, stirring, for 1 minute. 

Mix in the basmati rice. Cook over low heat for a few minutes, until the rice grains begin to look translucent. Then, stir in the 2.5 cups chicken stock. Cover and simmer until all the liquid is absorbed (~20 min).

Meanwhile, cube the chicken and heat some oil in a deep skillet.  Cook the chicken over high heat until golden on all sides.  Remove to a bowl.  

Add the remaining onion and cook until just beginning to brown around the edges. Crush in the 2 cloves of garlic, and mix in 1 tbsp ground ginger, and 2 tbsp curry powder. Season with the salt and pepper and cook 1 minute. 

Add back the cooked chicken and the remaining 1 cup chicken stock. Cover and simmer for 20 minutes, or until the chicken is tender. 

Finally, stir in the yogurt, and gently cook over low heat until warmed through.

If the sauce is not thick enough, dissolve the cornstarch in the water.  Bring the chicken mixture to a slow boil.  Immediately pour in the cornstarch mixture and stir until thickened.  Remove from the heat.

½ c shortening, cold
4 tsp caraway seeds (optional)
2 large eggs
½ c unsweetened applesauce
1 1/3 c buttermilk
1 tablespoon milk

Directions:

Put the raisins in a microwavable bowl and cover with 1 inch of water.  Heat for about 2 minutes.  Set aside to  cool.  Grease an 8-inch round pan.  Preheat the oven to 350 degrees.

In a large bowl, stir together the flour, baking powder, baking soda, salt, and sugar.  Cut in the shortening with a pastry blender until the mixture resembles coarse cornmeal.  Drain the raisins and gently dry them with a paper towel.  Stir in the caraway seeds and raisins.  Make a well in the center of the flour.  Beat the eggs into the well, then the applesauce.  Pour in the buttermilk and mix in all the flour.  

Knead several times in the bowl, using a spatula to make sure you get all the dough.  Turn the dough onto a lightly floured surface and knead for a few minutes.  Put the dough in the prepared pan and smooth the top.  Brush the top with the milk.  Cut a deep X on the top.  Bake for 40 - 50 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean.  Cool for 10 minutes, then remove from the pan and cool completely on a wire rack.  Store tightly wrapped.

½ teaspoon fennel seeds -- EXCLUDE these

Generous pinch of cayenne pepper -- add more... maybe 1/2 tsp

Cooking Instructions:
Prep:
Peel the eggplant so that it has stripes of skin. Slice it into medium-thin pieces. Place the slices onto a baking sheet and salt the top sides. Set the timer for 15 minutes, and let them sit.
 
Meanwhile, grate the graviera (or gruyere if substituting). When the timer goes off, flip the eggplant slices, salt them, and set the timer for another 15 minutes. 

At this point, set the oven to preheat to 350 degrees F. Mince the onion while the eggplant sits for its second round.
 
Directions:
Heat some olive oil in a large, deep skillet and toss in the onions with the bay leaves and the cinnamon stick. Let these caramelize on very low heat for 15 minutes.

When the timer for the eggplant goes off, rinse the eggplant slices thoroughly as well as the baking sheets. Oil the baking sheets, making sure to coat each side of each eggplant slice in the olive oil. Bake for 10 minutes at 350, flip the eggplant slices, and bake for another 10 minutes. They should be at least mostly cooked at this point, but will finish cooking when you bake the moussaka.
 
Once the onions are mostly caramelized, add the ground beef, 1 tsp cinnamon, ¼ tsp nutmeg, and 1/8 tsp ground cloves. Cook this until the meat is golden brown, and the onions are caramelized. Stir in the tomato paste. Then add the 28 oz crushed tomatoes, 1 tbsp red wine, 1 tbsp sugar, and 1 cup of water. Bring this to a boil and cook covered until half the liquid is reduced – about 20 minutes.
 
Once done, discard cinnamon and bay leaves and set aside.
 
In a medium saucepan, melt the butter. Add the flour 1 tbsp at a time, stirring constantly to ensure the rue stays smooth. ***Stir in the cinnamon and nutmeg.*** Then add the milk a little at a time, stirring constantly to avoid lumps. Once finished, pour this sauce into a blender with eggs. Blend until smooth and set aside.
 
To assemble, spread béchamel generously on the bottom of your baking dish. Alternate adding layers on meat sauce, eggplant slices, and béchamel, making sure to end with béchamel. Sprinkle generously with graviera. Bake until golden brown on top and bubbling at the sides – about 30-45 minutes.

Cooking Instructions:
2 lb chicken breasts

6 garlic cloves, peeled, crushed

1 tsp saffron threads, CRUSHED***
2 cups (or more) low-salt chicken broth

2 tbsp lemon juice

Prep: 
Sprinkle chicken with salt and pepper. Fry in a deep skillet over medium heat until golden, ~5 minutes per side.

Meanwhile, chop 2 cups onion and peel and crush 6 cloves garlic. Also, crush 1 tsp saffron with a mortar and pestle.

Directions: 
Transfer chicken to plate, and sauté the onions and garlic in the drippings until onions are slightly softened, 7 to 8 minutes.

At this point, add 2 cups white wine and the 1 tsp of crushed saffron. Bring to a boil and let it continue to boil until the liquid has thickened and reduced by less than half, ~8 minutes.

Move the skillet to the smallest burner. Add 2 cups chicken broth, and return the chicken to the skillet. Bring to a boil, then cover and let it simmer on very low heat for ~1 hour. Adjust the heat as needed to prevent boiling and turn the chicken over after 30 min.

After this, transfer the chicken to a plate to cool. Then, tear chicken into bite-size pieces and set aside. 

At this point, boil salted water for 1 lb pasta and cook it until al dente. When it's done, drain it and set it aside.

Meanwhile, add 1 cup heavy cream to the sauce in the original skillet and let it boil for ~10 min to reduce it. If needed add some cornstarch and water. It's done when it's ALMOST thick enough to coat a spoon. 

While the sauce reduces, you can julienne 2/3 cup of fresh basil.

Stir in 2 tablespoons lemon juice, then chicken pieces. Finally, mix in the pasta. Stir over medium heat until heated through, ~5 min. Add more broth in 2 oz portions to thin the sauce as needed and add more lemon juice by teaspoonful to taste, if desired. 

Finally, season with salt and pepper and stir in the 2/3 cup basil.

1) Place the meat on a rack and let it come to room temperature about 30 min to 1 hr before cooking, depending on the thickness of the cut.

2) Pat the steak dry meat before seasoning it because dry meat forms the best crust.

3) Preheat the pan to a high temperature. Ideally, use a cast-iron pan because it heats more evenly, ensuring the steak cooks evenly.

4) Season generously with Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper *immediately before* cooking. If you season it too early, the salt draws moisture out of the meat. 

5) Add a little bit of oil to the pan. As soon as the oil starts to smoke, that's when you should add the steak to the pan.

6) Cook the steak 3-5 min on each side until a brown crust forms. 
-- Flip multiple times: https://www.seriouseats.com/2012/12/the-food-lab-complete-guide-to-pan-seared-steaks.html#oil
-- Don't turn the steak and flip it only once. This lets the Maillard reaction create that signature taste on seared steak. https://www.foodandwine.com/how/grilling-mistakes-avoid-according-chefs

7) Cooking the steak to 5-10 degrees below the desired temp and then... 
-- Rare: 120-130°F
-- Medium rare: 130-135°F
-- Medium: 140-145°F
-- Medium Well: 150-155°F
-- Well: 160-165°F

8) Make sure to let the steak rest in a warm place after removing it from the pan. It will keep cooking slightly. Resting the steak allows the collagen in the meat to thicken the juices as it cools, creating a juicier steak.
-- Rest 5 min for thin cuts

½ tsp baking powder
¼ tsp salt
1 large egg
1 tsp peppermint extract
2 ¼ cups flour
red & green food coloring
sanding sugar for topping


Directions:
Prep
In the large bowl of a mixer, cream the butter and mix in the sugar, baking powder, and salt. Beat in the egg and peppermint extract. Then mix in the flour 1/3 at a time. Divide the dough into pieces that are 1/4, 3/8, and 3/8 of the dough. Mix the red and green food coloring into each of one of the large dough pieces in the mixer. Make sure to wash the bowl in between mixing the two colors.

Chill for 1 hour.

Main
Roll the dough into 6-inch long logs. Wrap various colored logs together, and shape into candy canes. Cover and chill for 30 minutes.

Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Place the cookies on a greased cookie sheet. Bake for 8 minutes or until no longer doughy. Cool on wire racks.

1 whole chicken
3 garlic cloves, finely chopped
1 tablespoon ground cumin
1 tablespoon olive oil
1 tablespoon paprika
1/2 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper
1/2 teaspoon dried oregano
1/2 teaspoons salt
3 tbsp lemon juice
1 tsp salt


Prep:
Arrange rack in middle of oven. Take out a roasting pan or a large oven-safe skillet. Peel the garlic.

Directions:
In a large bowl, mix 3 cloves of crushed garlic, 1 tbsp cumin, 1 tbsp paprika, 1 tbsp olive oil, 1/2 tsp oregano, 1/2 tsp salt, 1/2 tsp black pepper, and 3 tbsp lemon juice. 

Place chicken breast side down on work surface. Spatchcock chicken by cutting along both sides of backbone with kitchen shears. Remove backbone; reserve for stock. Turn chicken breast side up and splay open. Press down on breastbone with palms until you hear it crack and chicken is as flat as possible. Pat chicken dry with paper towels. 

At this point, preheat the oven to 400°F. 

From both edges of cavity, loosen skin from breasts and thighs, being careful not to tear skin. Gently spread 2 heaping tbsp spice mixture under skin, reserving the remaining spice mixture, then season chicken all over with remaining 1 tsp salt. Transfer the chicken, spread flat and skin side up, to the pan or skillet.

Roast chicken 20 minutes, then brush with spice mixture and pan juices. Continue roasting, basting with spice mixture and pan juices every 20 minutes, until juices run clear when thigh is pierced with a fork or an instant-read thermometer inserted into thickest part of thigh registers 165ºF, 50-60 minutes total.

Transfer chicken to a cutting board and let rest 15 minutes, reserving pan juices.

16 oz canned (not tubed) almond paste 
2 c sugar
3 egg whites
1/2 c pignoli


Preheat oven to 350 degrees.  Line 2 large cookie sheets with parchment paper.  Set aside.

Break the almond paste into small pieces and place in a food processor.  Process until nearly smooth.  With the processor running, gradually add the sugar through the feed tube, processing until combined.  Scrape down the sides and bottom.  Add the egg whites and process until combined.

Drop the dough by slightly rounded teaspoons onto the prepared cookie sheets.  Gently press about 6 - 12 nuts onto the top of each cookie.  Bake about 15 minutes, or until the edges are firm and the tops are lightly browned.

Cool on the cookies sheets for 3 - 4 minutes.  Transfer to a wire rack and cool completely.  If the cookies stick to the parchment paper, use a spatula dipped in hot water to remove them.  Makes about 24 cookies.

12 chicken drumsticks or wings
2 cups flour

Prep:
Make 1 recipe of the Piri Piri Marinade. Marinate the chicken in it at least 4 hours (best if marinated overnight). 

Strain the marinade and use the olive oil from it to fry the chicken. For each batch, fill a deep frying pan with 3/4 inch of the olive oil. Heat it until it starts to simmer.

Cover each piece of chicken in a dusting of flour and place it in the bubbling oil. Cook it for 10-20 minutes, turning at least once. Insert the meat thermometer in the thickest part of each piece. When it reaches 165 degrees, the chicken is fully cooked.

Cook the veggies from the marinade in a different pot and serve them over rice or corn.

1 habanero pepper
3 Serrano peppers
1 yellow onion
1 tbsp ginger paste
6 plum tomatoes
1 tbsp paprika 
1 tbsp oregano
salt & pepper to taste

Prep:
Dice 6 plum tomatoes and set aside in a large bowl. 

Get out a smaller bowl for the next chopped vegetables. Mince 3 cloves garlic, 1 habanero pepper, and 5 Thai chilis (OR 3 Serrano peppers as a substitute). Dice 1 medium yellow onion. Add 1 tbsp ginger paste and mix together.

Directions:
Measure 2 cups of olive oil. From that, remove 2 tbsp and heat them in a deep sauté pan. Cook the pepper/onion mixture over medium heat, stirring occasionally, until the vegetables are soft and the onions are translucent, 7-10 minutes. 

Add the chopped tomatoes, 2 tbsp tomato paste, 1 tbsp paprika, 1 tbsp oregano, and salt and black pepper to taste. Cook, stirring occasionally, until the tomatoes are soft, 5-8 minutes.

1 recipe Pie Dough
¼ lb sweet Italian sausage, skinned
1 Tbsp olive oil

3 thick slices prosciutto, chopped

Directions:

Ingredients: 3 cups flour,6 oz water,2 cups flour,1 tsp salt,3 tbsp honey,2 tbsp olive oil,4 oz water,1 tsp sugar,1.5 tsp yeast,0.5 cup water
Cooking Instructions:
In small bowl, combine 1/2 cup lukewarm water, 1.5 tsp yeast and 1 tsp sugar and set aside. The water should feel just slightly cooler than hot tub temperature. You can stir the yeast and even use the spoon to break up lumps.  It should look milky-colored and frothy when done.

Meanwhile, in a large bowl, add another 1/2 cup lukewarm water with 2 tbsp olive oil, 3 tbsp honey, and 1 tsp salt. Mix thoroughly before adding 3 cups of flour and mixing again. (When doubling the recipe, you might not need all 6 cups of flour here.)

Pausing between each addition, mix in 3/4 cup lukewarm water, 2 cups flour, and then the yeast mixture. Mix until the dough is sticky, but able to be handled for kneading.

Once ready, turn onto a lightly floured board and knead until smooth and elastic, adding flour as necessary.  Put in a large oiled bowl, turning to coat all sides.

Cover and let rise in a warm, draft-free place for 1 hour. Punch down dough. Divide and shape as desired.

** If you’re making bread, it needs to rise twice. The second time, you punch it down and put it in the pan. Bake for 40-50 minutes at 350 degrees. When it’s done, the crust should be golden brown, and the bottom should sound hollow when tapped.
Notes:
1.5 tsp = 1/4 oz = 1 average packet of yeast

This dough is also used for calzones and stromboli.

Cooking Instructions:
1/4 cup orange juice (about 1 medium orange)
1 tablespoon lime juice (about 1/2 lime)
2 tablespoons olive oil
1 tablespoon white wine vinegar (or apple cider vinegar)
1 tablespoon minced garlic (about 3 cloves)
1 tablespoon achiote powder (ground annatto seed) OR can substitute with paprika
1 tablespoon ground coriander
1 tablespoon coarse kosher salt
2 teaspoons smoked paprika
2 teaspoons dried oregano
1 teaspoon ground black pepper
1 teaspoon ground cumin
1/8 teaspoon ground cloves
2-3 pounds chicken

Prep:
INSTRUCTIONS
MARINADE: 
Add all ingredients except chicken in a small bowl. Whisk to combine.

Place chicken in a container and thoroughly coat it with the marinade. Refrigerate for 2 to 6 hours. **Do not marinate longer than 8 hours or the chicken will get tough and begin to break down.**

Prepare the grill: Preheat grill to medium heat (350°F-375°F) for indirect cooking. This means light the burners (or charcoal) on one half of the grill, and leave them off on the other half. This creates a zone of direct heat and a zone of indirect heat. Grease the preheated grill grates to prevent sticking by wiping them down with a folded paper towel that's been soaked in vegetable oil.

Grill: Remove the chicken from the marinade and shake off any excess liquid. Grill chicken skin side down over direct heat for about 8 to 10 minutes with the lid closed as much as possible, until the skin is crispy and golden. Flip chicken over, move to indirect heat and grill for 15 to 20 minutes, until the meat is firm and the temperature registers 165°F.
Notes:
Source: https://www.isabeleats.com/pollo-asado/#wprm-recipe-container-14347

Notes: 
- Don’t have achiote powder? You can leave it out completely or substitute regular paprika in its place. It won’t quite have the same flavor, but it will still be delicious!
- To make in the oven – Marinate chicken according to instructions above. Remove chicken from marinade and shake off any excess liquid. Place chicken on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper or foil and bake in a 400°F oven for 30-40 minutes depending on the thickness of the chicken. The internal temperature should read at least 165°F on an instant-read thermometer.
- To make in the slow cooker – Add all ingredients into a large slow cooker. Add 1/2 cup chicken broth or water, mix together to coat the chicken and cover. Cook on low for 6-7 hours or on high for about 3 hours.

Recipe Name: Raspberry Macarons with Chocolate Ganache Filling
Notes:
Ingredients

For the Meringue
200 grams confectioners' sugar
110 grams almonds
100 grams egg whites 
35 grams of granulated sugar
1 tsp raspberry extract
Pink food coloring gel/liquid
 
For the Ganache
6 ounces semisweet chocolate, chopped
1/3 cup heavy cream
2 tsp raspberry extract
 




Directions
For the Meringue
Line two large baking sheets with coated parchment paper.  In the bowl of a food processor, process the almonds and confectioners' sugar together until finely ground, about 2-3 minutes.  If using powdered food coloring, add it at this time; set aside.
 
In the bowl of a stand mixer fitted with the whisk attachment, beat the whites and salt on medium speed until foamy.  With the motor running, gradually add the granulated sugar, then increase speed to high and continue to beat until the whites hold soft, glossy peaks.  If using gel food coloring, fold it in at this time.  Using a runner spatula, fold in the almond mixture until it is thick and sticky.  When it is ready, the batter should drop from the spatula in a smooth molten mass. This will take about 1 minute or 50 strokes.
 
Spoon the batter into a pastry bag fitted with a large round tip (Ateco #808), pressing out excess air.  Twist the bag firmly just above the batter, then pipe 1 1/2-inch diameter rounds onto the prepared sheets, about 24 per sheet.  Tap the bottom of the baking sheets sharply, once, on the work surface to release any large air bubbles. Let the cookies stand, uncovered, at room temperature until the tops are no longer sticky and a light crust has formed, at least 30 minutes and up to an hour.
 
Meanwhile, start making the filling so that it cools in time.  Also, preheat the oven to 295° F. Bake the cookies until the tops are crisp and the bottoms dry, about 16 minutes.  Cool completely on racks.
 
For the Ganache
Chop the chocolate finely.  Add the chocolate and butter to a medium bowl.  In a small saucepan, heat the cream just until it comes to a simmer.  Pour the hot cream over the chocolate and let rest for five minutes.  Stir the chocolate until the mixture is smooth.  Stir in the raspberry extract.  Let stand at room temperature until cooled completely and thickened. 
 
To Assemble the Macarons
Carefully flip the cookies over on the baking sheets (they will be fragile) and partner them up in size.  Fill a pastry bag fitted with a round tip with the ganache and pipe or spoon kisses of ganache onto half of the cookie bottoms.  Sandwich the cookie halves together.  Enjoy immediately, or store in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to one week or in the freezer for up to one month.  Bon appétit!

Recipe Name: Rich Dark Chocolate Gelato (Gelato al Cioccolato Fondente)
Ingredients: 1 tsp Kahlua,4 oz dark chocolate chips,0.5 tsp vanilla extract,0.75 cup heavy cream,2.25 cups milk,2 tbsp cornstarch,0.5 cup Dutch-processed cocoa powder,0.75 cup sugar
Cooking Instructions:
OPTIONAL INGREDIENTS:
1/2 tsp vanilla extract, optional
1 tsp kahlua, optional

Prep: 
Weight out 4 oz. chocolate chips.

Directions:
For the base...
In a medium saucepan, mix 3/4 cup sugar, 2 tbsp cornstarch, and 1/2 cup cocoa powder. Then whisk in 1.25 cups of the milk and 3/4 cup cream.

Set over medium heat and bring to a boil while whisking constantly. Use a spatula and whisk alternately. The whisk doesn't scrape the chocolate off the bottom of the pan. As such, it will create a layer of burnt chocolate if you don't move the chocolate touching the bottom around throughout the process. Use the spatula for scraping the bottom and sides.

When it boils, add 1/2 tsp vanilla extract if desired. Then lower the heat to the minimum and simmer for about 4 min or until the mixture is thick and creamy.

Remove from the heat and mix in the chocolate chips until they're completely melted. Use a whisk to help remove lumps. Next, mix in the coffee liqueur, if using, and finally, whisk in the remaining milk. Uncovered, let cool to room temperature, then chill in the refrigerator for AT LEAST 6 hours.

Churning the gelato...
Strain the gelato base through a fine mesh strainer to help ensure a silky smooth texture. Pour into the bowl of the gelato machine and follow the manufacturer directions.* Stop the machine when the gelato is icy but still soft.

Transfer the gelato to an airtight container and freeze until firm, about two hours. The gelato will keep, frozen, for up to two weeks. Always take the gelato out to room temperature 10 to 15 minutes before serving to soften it and make it easier to scoop.

* See notes
Notes:
1 recipe makes about 2 pints

*Align the bowl with the arrows on the sides on the machine. Fill the bowl with the gelato base only up to the paddle's middle rung. Lock the lid. Set the machine to churn for 20-25min. One recipe takes 2 batches in the gelato machine. Between batches, thaw the bucket a little bit or the paddle will have a hard time stirring. It will cause the motor will overheat and stop churning the gelato.

30 minutes at 400, turning after 15 min.

Ingredients: pepper to taste,  salt to taste,6  globe artichoke(s),1 cup olive oil,3 cloves garlic,2 tbsp mint (fresh),2 tbsp parsley (fresh)
Cooking Instructions:
Prep: 
Finely chop 2 tbsp fresh flat-leaf parsley, 2 tbsp fresh mint, and 3 cloves garlic. Combine in a small bowl. Add 1-2 tbsp olive oil and season with salt and pepper to taste.

Fill a medium-size bowl with water and some lemon juice to prevent the artichokes from oxidizing when you prep them.

Rinse each artichoke and pull off its rough outer leaves. Cut the stem, leaving only a small piece. With a paring knife, remove the hard dark green leaf remnants around the base, trimming the area into a rounded shape. Cut off the upper tip of each artichoke so that the top is flat and even. Also, peel the rougher bits of the stems you removed so you can add them to the pan later.

Directions: 
Gently open each artichoke, and use a knife and/or a small spoon to remove all of the central downy heart (i.e. the "choke"). Fill the interior of each with the herb mixture and rub some of it on the outside of each one.

In a narrow saucepan, place the artichokes VERY tightly together to prevent them from opening during cooking. **They should be standing face-down, stem-up.** Pour over the remaining olive oil, then add 1/2 cup water.

Cover the pan and cook over moderate heat for ~25 min or until they are tender and the sauce has reduced. They can be served hot or cold.

Cooking Instructions:
2 sticks butter, softened
1 ½ cups confectioner’s sugar
1 tsp vanilla
2 ¼ cups flour
¼ tsp salt
¾ cup walnuts


Directions:
Prep
Take the butter out to soften. Grind up the walnuts finely in the food processor.

In the large bowl of a mixer, cream the butter and mix in ½ cup of the confectioner’s sugar and vanilla. Add the flour and salt. Beat in the walnuts and chill for 1 hour.

Main
Preheat the oven to 375 degrees. Roll the dough into 1-inch balls. Place them onto a cookie sheet lined with parchment paper.

Bake for 10-12 minutes until set but not browned. While the cookies are warm, roll each one in the remaining sugar. Let the cookies cool and then roll them again.

Ingredients: 35 oz peeled tomatoes,3 cloves garlic,1 tbsp mint (fresh),1 tbsp basil (fresh),1 pinch nutmeg (fresh grated),0.5 cup white bread crumbs,2  egg(s),1 cup pecorino romano,0.5 lb veal (ground),4 oz white wine,2  bay leaves,1  onion(s),3  eggplant(s)
Cooking Instructions:
Prep:
Slice each of the 3 medium eggplants in half. Using a spoon, scoop the flesh out, leaving a 1/4-inch-thick shell. Chop the scooped out eggplant flesh and add it to the colander. Toss the chopped eggplant with 2 tbsp of kosher salt and let drain for 30 minutes.

Meanwhile, bring a large pot of salted water to a boil. Set a wire rack on a baking sheet. Add the 6 eggplant shells to the pot and cook, gently poking them under to keep them submerged, until just tender, about 3 minutes. Using a slotted spoon, transfer the eggplant shells to the wire rack to drain and cool.

Chop the onion and crush the bay leaves into a powder while the chopped eggplant is being salted and the shells are cooling.

Rinse the salt off the chopped eggplant thoroughly and squeeze out as much of the water as possible. This should yield about 4 cups of chopped eggplant. 

Directions: 
Lightly oil a 9-by-13-inch baking dish and arrange the eggplant shells in it, cut sides up.

In a large, deep skillet, heat 3 tbsp of olive oil until shimmering. Add the onion and bay leaf powder and cook over moderate heat until the onion is softened, about 5 minutes. Add the chopped eggplant and wine and cook over moderate heat, stirring occasionally, until tender and just beginning to brown, 15 minutes. Add the veal and cook over moderately high heat, stirring and breaking up the meat, until cooked through and lightly browned, about 5 minutes longer. 

Transfer the eggplant filling to a bowl and stir in 1/2 cup of the pecorino, 2 eggs, 1/2 cup bread crumbs, nutmeg, basil and mint. Season the filling with salt and pepper. Spoon the filling into the eggplant shells.

Preheat the oven to 350°. In a medium saucepan, heat 1 tablespoon of olive oil. Add the garlic and cook over moderate heat until golden, about 1 minute. Add the chopped tomatoes and cook over moderate heat, stirring, until thickened, about 10 minutes. Season with salt and pepper. Spoon half of the sauce over the eggplants and sprinkle with the remaining 1/2 cup of grated pecorino. 

Bake the eggplant until browned and bubbling, about 35 minutes. Let cool slightly, then serve, passing the remaining tomato sauce on the side.

Ingredients: 2 lb salmon,0.5 cup sesame seeds,2 tsp cornstarch,1  egg white(s),3 tbsp water,1.5 tsp ginger paste,1 cloves garlic,2 tbsp sherry,0.5 tsp sugar,0.25 cup soy sauce,0.5 cup chicken bouillon broth
Cooking Instructions:
Prep:
Make 1/2 cup chicken broth from chicken bouillon & water. In a small bowl, combine 1/4 cup soy sauce, 2 tbsp sherry, 1/2 cup chicken broth, 1/2 tsp sugar, 1.5 tsp ginger. Crush 1 clove into the bowl and mix thoroughly.

Directions:
Whisk together 1 egg white and the 2 tbsp cornstarch. Slice the salmon into individual pieces. Brush the skinless side of the salmon with the egg-white mixture and then dip it into the sesame seeds to coat.

In a large nonstick frying pan, heat some olive oil over moderately high heat. Cook the salmon, sesame-seed side down, for ~5 mins. Flip and cook ~3 more mins until the middle is cooked.

Meanwhile, in another small bowl, stir together the 2 teaspoons cornstarch and the water. Once finished cooking salmon, pour any oil from the pan. Add the soy-sauce mixture and simmer for 2 minutes. Whisk in the cornstarch/water mixture. Continue whisking as it simmers until it thickens, about 1 minute longer.

Serve the salmon with the sauce poured around it.
Notes:
- Can substitute masala or generic red cooking wine for the sherry.
- Adjust amount of sesame seeds as needed
- Can use tuna steaks instead if desired.
- Can use chicken instead of salmon if desired. In that case, marinate the chicken in the sauce overnight.

Ingredients: 1  tomato(es),0.33 cup mayonnaise,0.5 cup canola oil,1 cup flour,1 cup cornmeal,4 tsp Emeril's Essence,0.5 cup hot sauce,2 lb shrimp
Cooking Instructions:
Prep:
Devein and peel the shrimp. 

Main:
Toss the shrimp with hot sauce and Essence. In another bowl, mix the cornmeal and flour. Toss the shrimp in the cornmeal mixture and fry in a skillet until golden brown on both sides. Pat off the grease with paper towels.

Slice a baguette. On each slice, spread mayo and hot sauce. Layer the sandwiches with tomato and shrimp.

Ingredients: 4 oz dark chocolate chips,0.75 cup heavy cream,2.25 cups milk,1 tbsp vanilla extract,2 tbsp cornstarch,0.75 cup sugar
Cooking Instructions:
Ingredients
2 1⁄4 cups cups whole milk
3⁄4 cup heavy cream
1 vanilla bean, split lengthwise or 1 tbsp pure vanilla extract
3⁄4 cup sugar
2 tbsp. cornstarch
1 egg yolk


Prep: 
In a small bowl, whisk together 1 cup milk, 3/4 cup sugar, and 2 tbsp cornstarch. 

Directions:
For the base...
In a medium saucepan, 1.25 cups of the milk and 3/4 cup cream. Then add the split vanilla bean or 1 tbsp vanilla extract. Warm over low-medium heat until it just starts to bubble around the edge (no need to bring it to a boil), especially because you don't want it to curdle.

Meanwhile, In a small bowl, whisk the remaining 1 cup (250 ml) milk, sugar, and cornstarch together. Remove the saucepan with the hot milk from the heat and whisk in the cornstarch mixture. Return the saucepan to medium heat and cook, stirring regularly, until the sugar is dissolved and the mixture thickens slightly, 6 to 8 minutes.

Place the egg yolk in a medium bowl and whisk until pale and thickened, 30 seconds to 1 minute. Temper the egg yolk by slowly pouring one ladleful of the hot milk mixture into the yolk, whisking constantly, then slowly pour the egg yolk mixture back into the saucepan, whisking to combine.

Remove from the heat. Uncovered, let cool to room temperature, then chill in the refrigerator for AT LEAST 6 hours.

If using a vanilla bean, fish it out of the custard. (You can rinse the used vanilla bean under cold water, pat it dry, then add it to a jar of brown sugar to keep it moist and infuse some of the vanilla flavor into it.)

Churning the gelato...
Strain the gelato base through a fine mesh strainer to help ensure a silky smooth texture. Pour into the bowl of the gelato machine and follow the manufacturer directions.* Stop the machine when the gelato is thick and icy but still easily spoonable.

Transfer the gelato to an airtight container and freeze until firm, about two hours. The gelato will keep, frozen, for up to two weeks. Always take the gelato out to room temperature 10 to 15 minutes before serving to soften it and make it easier to scoop.

* See notes
Notes:
1 recipe makes about 2 pints

*Align the bowl with the arrows on the sides on the machine. Fill the bowl with the gelato base only up to the paddle's middle rung. Lock the lid. Set the machine to churn for 20-25min. Stop the machine when the gelato is thick and icy but still easily spoonable. One recipe takes 2 batches in the gelato machine. Between batches, thaw the bucket a little bit or the paddle will have a hard time stirring. It will cause the motor will overheat and stop churning the gelato.

Cooking Instructions:
3 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil
1 cup finely chopped onion
5 scallions, trimmed and finely chopped (about 3/4 cup)
2 tablespoons minced garlic (~2 cloves?)
Freshly ground black pepper
32 oz fresh spinach, washed, dried, trimmed, and coarsely chopped
2 large eggs
8 oz crumbled feta
2 tbsp dried parsley (or 1/3 cup fresh)
1 tsp oregano
½ cup/115 grams unsalted butter (1 stick), melted
8 sheets frozen phyllo dough, thawed and halved crosswise (16 oz package)

Prep:
Trim the stems off the fresh spinach leaves (optional). 

Chop 1 cup onion. Trim and chop 3/4 cup of scallions (about 5 full stalks). Crush 2 large cloves of garlic.

Thaw the phyllo dough.

Directions:
In a large pot, heat oil over medium. Add 1 cup onion, 3/4 cup scallions, 2 large cloves of garlic, and freshly ground black pepper to taste. Cook, stirring occasionally, until softened, 5 minutes.

In batches, stir in spinach until wilted. Strain spinach mixture through a sieve, pressing out excess liquid to prevent a soggy crust. Transfer to a large bowl and cool for 5 minutes.

Pulse 8 oz feta in a food processor until it's finely crumbled. Add spinach mixture to a food processor and pulse until the mixture is very fine, but not a paste-like consistency.

Transfer the mixture back to the bowl, and mix in 2 eggs, 2 tbsp parsley, and 1 tsp oregano.

At this point, preheat oven to 375 degrees. 

Lightly grease a 9-by-13-inch pan (2 inches deep) with butter. Lay one half sheet of phyllo dough in baking dish. Using a pastry brush, brush dough with butter. Repeat 7 more times to form crust. 

Spread spinach mixture evenly over crust. Brush one half sheet of phyllo dough with butter and lay on top of filling, butter side up. Repeat with remaining 7 sheets of dough. 

Using a serrated knife, lightly score top layer of dough into squares (this will make it easier to cut once baked). Bake until crust is lightly golden and filling is heated through, 45-60 minutes.

Ingredients: 0.5 tsp salt,1 tsp red pepper flakes,1 tsp mustard seeds,2 tbsp cilantro (fresh),1  green chili pepper(s),2  russet potato(es)
Cooking Instructions:
Prep:
Preheat the oven to 400˚F. Pierce several holes in 2 large potatoes and parboil them. 

Place the potatoes on a baking sheet, rub them with olive oil, and sprinkle with salt and black pepper. Roast them in the oven for 1 hour or until the potatoes are soft all the way through. You should be able to stick a fork into them with no resistance. 

Directions:
Let the potatoes cool just enough to handle. Meanwhile, chop 1 green chili and 2 tbsp fresh cilantro.

Remove the potato skins and thoroughly mash the potatoes. Mix in the green chili, the cilantro, 1 tsp mustard seeds, 1 tsp chili flakes, and 1/2 tsp salt.
Notes:
Adapted from: p. 54 of "My Bangladesh Kitchen" by Saira Hamilton
- This is the filling from the Aloo Poori recipe

Cooking Instructions:
Ingredients:

1 ½ tbsp butter
1 clove garlic, minced
2 oz. clam juice
5 oz. drained canned clams, juice reserved
1 tsp parsley
¼ tsp paprika
1/8 tsp salt
1/8 tsp black pepper
5 ½ oz. cream of celery soup
¼ cup grated parmesan
10 Ritz cracker, finely ground
6 slices bread, finely ground


Directions:

Prep
Preheat oven to 350 degrees.

Main
In a medium saucepan, melt the butter and sauté the garlic. Add all the clam juice, clams, parsley, paprika, salt, and pepper. Cook 1 minute at low heat. Stir in the cream of celery soup. Heat slightly.

After removing from heat, mix in the cheese, crackers, and bread crumbs. Spray a non-stick baking sheet. Ball the mixture and bake for 15 minutes.

https://www.isabeleats.com/homemade-taco-seasoning-recipe/

4 tablespoons chili powder
1 tsp dried oregano
2 tsp garlic powder
2 tsp onion powder
2 tsp paprika
1 tsp cayenne
1.5 tsp ground cumin


- Watching your salt intake? Simply leave out the salt in this recipe and just add it as needed during the cooking process.

- Like your taco seasoning on the spicy side? Add 1 tablespoon ground cayenne pepper or red pepper flakes to the mix.

- Want more of a smoky flavor? Use smoked paprika instead of regular paprika. You could also add some ground chipotle powder.

***NOTE: When making ground beef, chicken or turkey tacos, I recommend using 2 tablespoons of seasoning per 1 pound of ground meat.***

Dal
¾ cup dried moong dal (split yellow mung beans) (about 5½ ounces)
¾ cup dried masoor dal (split red lentils) (about 5 ounces)
¾ cup dried toor dal (split pigeon peas) (about 5¾ ounces)
2 ½ teaspoons kosher salt, plus more to taste
1 ½ teaspoons ground turmeric
4 to 5 cups water, divided
1 ½ tablespoons canola oil
4 green cardamom pods, crushed, shells discarded
4 whole cloves
1 ¼ teaspoons cumin seeds
1 medium-size yellow onion, finely chopped (about 2 cups)
2 medium-size fresh serrano chiles, stemmed, seeded if desired, and finely chopped (about 2 1/2 tablespoons)
1 medium tomato, chopped (about 1 cup)
¼ cup roughly chopped fresh cilantro, plus more for garnish

Tadka
3 tablespoons ghee
3 small dried chiles (such as Diaspora Co. Whole Sannam Chillies), or more to taste
1 teaspoon cumin seeds



Begin the tadka dal
Step 1
Stir together moong dal, masoor dal, toor dal, salt, turmeric, and 4 cups water in a large saucepan; bring to a boil over medium-high. Reduce heat to medium-low; partially cover, and cook, stirring occasionally, until dal is soft and tender, 35 to 40 minutes. Add up to remaining 1 cup water, 1/4 cup at a time, until desired thickness and consistency is reached.

Continue making the tadka dal
Step 3
Heat oil in a medium-size heavy-bottomed saucepan over medium. Add cardamom, cloves, and cumin; cook, stirring constantly, until fragrant, 30 to 45 seconds. 


Add onion and serrano chiles; cook, stirring often, until onion is lightly browned around edges, 5 to 8 minutes. Add tomato; cook, stirring often, until tomato begins to break down, 2 to 4 minutes. Remove from heat. 

Add tomato mixture and cilantro to dal mixture; stir to combine. Season to taste with salt. Cover and keep warm over low.

Just before serving, make the tadka
Step 6
In a small skillet, heat ghee over medium-high. Add dried chiles and cumin to pan; cook, stirring occasionally, until cumin is toasted and fragrant, about 30 seconds. Divide dal mixture among bowls, and drizzle each portion with desired amount of warm tadka. Sprinkle with additional cilantro, and serve alongside hot roti.
Notes:
Source: https://www.foodandwine.com/recipes/tadka-dal-with-roti

"Briefly heating spices and dried chiles in oil or ghee allows their flavors to bloom, creating a flavorful tadka that serves as the backbone of this dish. It also adds a crispy, spicy finish to the creamy mixture of mung beans, lentils, and pigeon peas."
Source: p. 233 of "My Bangladesh Kitchen" by Saira Hamilton

Ingredients: 2 tbsp kasoori methi,2 tsp garam masala,2 tsp cumin,1 tbsp coriander,1 cup yogurt,  salt to taste,2 tbsp ghee,2 tbsp lemon juice,1 tsp garlic paste,1 tsp ginger paste,0.5 cup chili powder,16 lb whole turkey,4 lb whole chicken
Cooking Instructions:

Wash off whole chicken inside out, and remove all the skin. Pat it dry thoroughly with paper towels. Then make gashes all over so that the masala can permeate the chicken. NOTE: Doing this first allows the chicken to come to room temperature while you make the first marinade.

Directions:
For the first marinade, mix 1/4 cup red chili powder, 2 tbsp lemon juice, 2 tbsp melted ghee, 1 tsp ginger paste, and 1 tsp garlic paste. Rub this masala on both the inside and outside of the chicken, including inside the gashes. 

Set the chicken aside to rest for 15 minutes. Meanwhile, make the second marinade by mixing 1/4 cup red chili powder, 1 tbsp coriander powder, 2 tsp cumin powder, 2 tsp garam masala, 2 tbsp kasoori methi, turmeric for color, salt to taste, and 1 cup plain yogurt. Rub this masala on both the inside and outside of the chicken, including inside the gashes.

Cover the chicken and let it marinate in the fridge overnight. Remove chicken from the fridge 30 minutes before you want to cook it. Place a grill rack on top of a deep baking dish (such as a lasagna dish) and transfer the chicken to this. Cover the chicken with some aluminum foil. At approx. this point, preheat the oven to 325.

CHICKEN ROAST TIMES: ???
Bake the turkey at 325 for ?? min. Increase the heat to 400. Meanwhile, remove the aluminum foil. Bake the turkey at 400 for ?? min. Take out the turkey and flip it onto its other side on the grill rack. Return it to the oven bake it at 400 for a final ?? min.

16 LB TURKEY ROAST TIMES:
Bake the turkey at 325 for 40 min. Increase the heat to 400. Meanwhile, remove the aluminum foil. Bake the turkey at 400 for 45 min. Take out the turkey and flip it onto its other side on the grill rack. Ingredients: 2 tbsp kasoori methi,2 tsp garam masala,2 tsp cumin,1 tbsp coriander,  salt to taste,2 tbsp ghee,2 tbsp lemon juice,1 tsp garlic paste,1 tsp ginger paste,0.5 cup chili powder
Cooking Instructions:
Directions:
Mix 1/2 cup red chili powder, 1 tbsp coriander powder, 2 tsp cumin powder, 2 tsp garam masala, 2 tbsp kasoori methi, and some turmeric for color. 

Melt 2 tbsp ghee. 

Meanwhile mix in 1 tsp ginger paste, 1 tsp garlic paste, and 2 tbsp lemon juice. Then, mix in the melted ghee.

Salt the final marinade to taste.

*Note: Add 1 cup plain yogurt for a thicker, creamier marinade.

Ingredients: 0.5 tsp lemon zest,  pepper to taste,  salt to taste,1 tbsp water,1 tbsp cornstarch,1 tsp tarragon,4 oz crème fraîche,0.5 cup chicken bouillon broth,6 oz white wine,3 cloves garlic,3  shallot(s),1 lb chicken breasts
Cooking Instructions:
Prep:
Mince 3 small shallots and crush 3 cloves garlic.

Slice the chicken breasts in half crosswise to make them thinner.

Directions:
In a deep skillet, heat some olive oil and cook the chicken for 3-5 minutes on each side until both sides are golden brown. Once each piece reaches 165ºF internally, remove it to a plate and set aside.

Next, sauté the shallots and garlic in a little olive oil until they have softened and turned slightly golden. Add 2/3 cup white wine to deglaze the pan and let it simmer for a few minutes until it has reduced slightly. Use a wooden spoon to stir the mixture and to lift any caramelized bits from the pan.

Meanwhile, mix 1/2 cup chicken stock, 1/2 cup crème fraîche, and 1 tsp dried tarragon. Add this mixture to the skillet and let the sauce simmer gently for a few minutes. Season with salt and pepper to taste.

In a small bowl, mix 1 tbsp cornstarch and 1 tbsp water. Drizzle this slurry into the sauce while stirring the sauce constantly to avoid creating lumps. Let the sauce simmer for 1-2 minutes until it has thickened.

Turn the heat down to low, return the chicken to the skillet, and cook  with the lid on for 10 minutes. Finally, add 1/2 tsp lemon zest.

Optionally, garnish with parsley or more tarragon before serving.
Source: p. 108 of "My Bangladesh Kitchen" by Saira Hamilton

Ingredients: 1 tsp salt,2 tsp sugar,1 tsp garlic powder,2 tbsp oregano,2 tbsp basil,1 tbsp parsley,28 oz crushed tomatoes,28 oz tomato puree,12 oz tomato paste,2 tsp fennel seeds,4 cloves garlic,6 oz water,2 tbsp olive oil
Cooking Instructions:
Prep:
Open the cans of tomato. Peel the garlic. 

Directions:
In a very large, deep pot, heat the oil over medium. Lightly sauté the garlic, fennel seeds, and crushed red pepper.  Do not brown!

Add the crushed tomatoes, tomato puree, and tomato paste.  Use the water to rinse out the cans, then add it to the sauce.  Mix well.  Stir in all the remaining ingredients.

Bring to a boil.  Reduce the heat to low, use a diffuser, and simmer, stirring often, at least 2 hours.
Notes: If cooking meatballs in the sauce, simmer at least 1 hour, add the meatballs, then cook for at least another 1 1/2 hours.

Recipe Name: Tomato Za'atar Soup with Halloumi Croutons

Cooking Instructions:
Prep:
Rinse and boil ~1 cup split red lentils for 5 minutes. Drain and weigh out 1/2 lb of the cooked lentils.

Directions:
Preheat a grill, and soak 10 wooden skewers.
In a large mixing bowl, combine all ingredients except lettuce and tzatziki. Mix thoroughly until a sticky consistency is reached.
Shape into 10 equal kofte around the end of 10 skewers. Each kofte should be roughly 3-4 inches long.
Grill the kofte for 8-10 minutes, or until cooked through.
Serve in a lettuce wrap with 2 oz of tzatziki and extra dash of sumac if desired.

For best results, chill them before baking for at least 30 minutes. 

Bake 15-20 minutes at 400˚F.
Served with grated parmigiano-reggiano and fresh cracked black pepper.

Ingredients: 0.75 cup milk,0.75 cup heavy cream,2 oz vodka,  pepper to taste,  salt to taste,0.5 tsp red pepper flakes,1 tsp basil,4.5 oz tomato paste,2 tbsp olive oil,4 cloves garlic,1  onion(s),4 oz parmigiano reggiano
Cooking Instructions:
Prep:
Grate 4 oz parmigiano-reggiano. 

Mince 1 onion. Crush 4 cloves garlic. 

Directions:
With 2 tbsp olive oil, sauté the onion and garlic a sauce pot or Dutch oven over medium heat. Cook, stirring constantly, until the onion starts to brown around the edges, 5–7 minutes.

Mix in 4.5-oz. tube tomato paste, 1 tsp basil, 1/2 tsp red pepper flakes, and salt and pepper to taste. Continue to cook, stirring often, until paste is deep red and starting to brown on bottom of pot, 5–7 minutes.

Deglaze the pan with 2 oz. vodka. Heat 3/4 cup cream and 3/4 cup milk slightly in the microwave before adding them to the sauce. This helps avoid curdling from the temperature shock. Stir in the grated cheese until the sauce is smooth.
Notes:
Can substitute white wine for vodka if desired.

Source: https://www.bonappetit.com/recipe/rigatoni-with-easy-vodka-sauce

Ingredients: 1.75 cups milk,2  egg(s),1 tsp salt,1 tsp baking powder,2 tbsp sugar,2 cups flour,6 tbsp butter (unsalted)
Cooking Instructions:
Prep:
Melt 6 tbsp butter and set it aside to cool.

Separate 2 eggs - the whites go into the bowl of the electric mixer and the yolks go into a medium-sized mixing bowl.

Directions:
While you beat the egg whites in the mixer until soft peaks form, whisk together the egg yolks and 1 3/4 cups milk.

Transfer the egg whites into a small bowl for now. 

In the bowl of the mixer, now combine 2 cups flour, 2 tbsp sugar, 1 tbsp baking powder, and 1 tsp salt. Add 1/2 tsp cinnamon and 1/4 tsp nutmeg if desired. Whisk the milk and egg yolk mixture into this. Then whisk in the cooled, melted butter until the batter is smooth.

Finally, gently fold in the egg whites.

Spray and preheat a waffle iron at setting #2 or #3 depending on how dark you like your waffles.

 Fill the waffle iron just enough that nothing spills out when you bring down the top of the iron. Let cook until the light on the waffle maker turns green. Leave longer if you want it browner. Then remove carefully with a fork and a spatula.

Serve with a topping such as butter, maple syrup, fresh fruit, jam, peanut butter, Nutella, honey, apple butter, pumpkin butter, etc
Notes: You can add cinnamon and nutmeg if desired.

Cooking Instructions:
6 tbsp butter****
2 tbsp spicy mustard
2 tbsp horseradish
3 tbsp poppy seeds
4 tbsp red onion, finely chopped
1 loaf Italian bread
¾ lb. chicken breast, thinly sliced
½ lb. Swiss cheese, sliced

Prep
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Chop 4 tbsp red onion. 

Directions:
Microwave the butter with the mustard, horseradish, and red onion. Stir in the poppy seeds. Slice the bread in half and spread this mixture on each side. Layer on the chicken and cheese.

Wrap in aluminum foil and bake for 20 minutes. Let stand for 5 minutes before slicing into individual sandwiches.
